title: Monday briefing: Groping claims about PM overshadow Tory conference
text:
Top story: ‘I clearly have a better memory than he does’

Good morning and welcome to this Monday briefing with Alison Rourke.

The Conservatives will be hoping to get their party conference back on track after allegations over the PM’s behaviour overshadowed the first day. The prime minister is said to be furious at the claims by journalist Charlotte Edwardes that at a private lunch in 1999, Johnson touched her leg under a table, grabbing “enough inner flesh beneath his fingers” to make her “sit upright”. Downing Street insiders privately described the claims as “bollocks” and “nonsense”. Edwardes tweeted on Sunday night: “If the prime minister doesn’t recollect the incident then clearly I have a better memory than he does.” Johnson also remains under pressure over his relationship with American tech entrepreneur Jennifer Arcuri, whose company received a public grant. Conference delegates, meanwhile, can expect plenty of references to the “surrender act” after the PM refused to moderate his language and repeated the phrase a dozen times on the BBC’s Andrew Marr programme yesterday.

Whistleblower safety – Lawyers acting for the whistleblower at the centre of the impeachment scandal say President Trump’s remarks are putting their client in danger. Andrew Bakaj said Trump’s demands to know the identity of the whistleblower have led to safety concerns, and a $50,000 reward for information that would identify him or her. Bakaj has called on senior Democratic and Republican leaders to “speak out in favour of whistleblower protection”. On Sunday night, Trump tweeted: “I deserve to meet my accuser, especially when this accuser, the so-called ‘Whistleblower’, represented a perfect conversation with a foreign leader in a totally inaccurate and fraudulent way”. He also quoted a Fox News guest who said “removing the President from office (which they will never be), it will cause a Civil War like fracture in this Nation from which our Country will never heal”. It followed a weekend of Trump defenders, led by his lawyer Rudy Guiliani, attacking the unnamed whistleblower in an attempt to push back against the rapidly intensifying impeachment inquiry. Last week Trump compared the whistleblower to a spy.

Vocational training – The education secretary, Gavin Williamson, will announce plans today to launch a further eight institutes of technology, a collaboration between further education colleges, universities and employers to offer higher-level technical training. Williamson, who will announce the policy at the party conference, will say courses could become more popular than universities and that the new institutes of technology are intended to end the sector’s image as a poor relation. They come on top of an additional £400m in funding for further education and sixth-form colleges announced at the end of last month.

Far-right vote collapses – Austria’s Freedom party has lost more than a third of its support, in elections in which it was punished over a corruption scandal that brought down the government. The former chancellor Sebastian Kurz, 33, looks certain to reclaim his position as the youngest leader in the world after his conservative People’s party (ÖVP) secured 37.1% of the vote – its best result since 2002. The Freedom party’s vote fell to 16%, while the Green party jumped to its best result at national elections with 14%. Kurz signalled on Sunday night that he was willing to enter coalition talks with both the Freedom party and the Green party.

Heart attacks – Women are dying from heart attacks unnecessarily because of the mistaken perception that they mostly happen to men. Inequalities at every stage lead to women being diagnosed late and not getting the prompt treatment and aftercare they need to survive a heart attack, according to the British Heart Foundation. Research shows that more than 8,000 women died between 2002 and 2013 in England and Wales because they did not receive the same standard of care as men.

Asleep at the wheel? – There are calls for truck drivers to be routinely tested for sleep apnoea after an Italian study found that half suffer from breathing disorders. The survey of 905 truck drivers found that approximately half suffered from at least one sleep-related breathing problem that could potentially cause them to fall asleep at the wheel. Researchers found that 77% were overweight or obese. According to Luca Roberti, president of the Italian sleep apnoea patient association, “this is due to a lifestyle that forces the drivers to sit for several hours a day, with little physical activity and a poor diet, leading to a greater risk of excessive daytime sleepiness and of dozing off unexpectedly while driving.”

Today in Focus podcast: Is it over for Justin Trudeau?

Justin Trudeau achieved a historic victory in 2015 but as he nears the end of his first term a series of scandals are making his political future far less certain. With Canada going to the polls next month, journalist Leyland Cecco discusses how likely it is Trudeau will repeat his initial success And: Kaitlyn Regehr on why new sex education lessons in schools are already outdated.

Lunchtime read: ‘Now it’s just ghosts’

Four years of war has devastated Yemen, bringing suffering beyond recognition, writes Bethan McKernan, who has travelled on a rare 6,000km journey through the country’s patchwork of factions in its bitter civil war: “Death comes from above at any time. Over a lunch of chicken, rice and sweet honeyed fatteh, the unmistakable thud of a nearby missile shook the windows of a restaurant. The diners paid no attention to the whine of the Saudi warplane even as it circled back for a second, third and fourth hit.

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Mustafa al-Adel shows the place where his brother’s body was found on 11 September 2019. Photograph: Achilleas Zavallis/Achilleas Zavallis for The Guardian

“But the regional power’s scorched earth policy in this proxy war has brought it no closer to victory. With Iran’s help, the Houthi forces now possess sophisticated drone technology and can launch cross-border rocket attacks deep into Saudi Arabia, targeting assets such as oilfields, military bases and airports. Some call this the Kingdom’s Vietnam, but it could be much, much worse. The victims are ordinary Yemenis, who are paying an extraordinary price.”

Sport

Dina Asher-Smith was able to savour a stunning 100m personal best, a new national record of 10.83sec and, most of all, a sparkling silver medal after finishing behind the legendary Jamaican Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce at the World Athletics Championships in Doha. Australia’s rugby vice-captain, Samu Kerevi, has called on authorities to bring in players to advise on the regulations covering the contact area, fearing that the game will cease to be a collision sport and become “soft”, after he was penalised in the game against Wales on Sunday. Beauden, Jordie and Scott Barrett will become the first trio of brothers to appear for the All Blacks in a World Cup match after they were named to start for the three-times world champions against Canada. Riyad Mahrez decorated Manchester City’s victory against Everton on Saturday with a glittering display that left Pep Guardiola purring over his “gift”. And cycling’s world time trial champion Rohan Dennis, who defended his crown just last week in Harrogate, has had his contract with race team Bahrain-Merida terminated with immediate effect.

Business

Sir Philip Green’s Miss Selfridge chain posted a £17.5m loss last year as sales fell and it wrote down the value of loss-making stores. Sales at the youth fashion chain fell more than 15% to £102m in the year to 1 September 2018, while pretax losses more than quadrupled from £4.3m a year before. Losses widened after more than £12m in one-off costs mostly related to property writedowns were added, as well as redundancies.

The pound is buying $1.229 and €1.124.

The papers

Facebook Twitter Pinterest Photograph: The Guardian

Boris Johnson remains front and centre on many of today’s papers, with the Telegraph reporting a “Plot to force Johnson into Brexit extension”, in a story that claims opposition leaders will meet to see how they can force him into requesting an extension of Article 50. The Mirror says the PM’s connection with US businesswoman Jennifer Arcuri is an “abuse of power”. The FT has “DUP balks at Johnson plans”. The Mail also carries a picture of Johnson with the headline: “Boris’s blonde ‘told her friends they DID have an affair” (but saves the most space for “Women driven to the brink by care crisis”). The Guardian has “Prime minister forced into denial of claims he groped two women”, but it saves its splash for the devastating civil war in Yemen.

The Express gives Johnson some support before his party’s conference: “Boris rally cry: get Brexit done to fix divided Britain” but leads on “Bumper rise for pensions”. The Times ignores Johnson and and Brexit altogether and opts for “Children face ban from school if not vaccinated”. The i also splashes on that story with “Compulsory vaccinated targeted for UK children”.

And the Sun has splashed on an “exclusive” about the “Purrminator”, a “monster puss(cat)” on the loose in Hampstead.
